awd_titl_txt: Engineering biosynthesis and incorporation of an immunogenic amino acid
awd_abstract_narration:
Live bacterial vaccines can be engineered to more effectively trigger a desired immune response to prevent infection. This project examines an approach to making more effective live bacterial vaccines by engineering the bacteria to introduce certain atypical protein building blocks, called non-native amino acids (NNAAs), into their proteins.  These NNAAs could help stimulate an immune response against proteins in bacteria that would usually evade the immune response, thus leading to more effective vaccines. As part of this project, undergraduate students will receive mentoring and resources to conduct projects related to non-standard amino acids.

Metabolic engineering strategies will be utilized to create a de novo biochemical pathway that forms a nitroaromatic amino acid. The nitro chemical functional group has scarcely been explored as a product of metabolic engineering. Therefore, the stability and toxicity of relevant nitro compounds will be explored. In parallel, the substrate specificity of engineered aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase and tRNA pairs will be examined in order to facilitate template-directed incorporation of this amino acid within proteins. This project will also study whether the immunogenic amino acid can be introduced to a model bacterial antigen without disrupting key structural features, and how the mouse immune system responds to the modified and unmodified antigen. Overall, this project will generate foundational knowledge and tools that may lead to the first application of metabolic engineering to vaccine research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we investigated strategies to enable a benign bacterium to produce a chemistry that can help the immune system identify desired protein antigens. Unlike prior efforts that relied on chemical synthesis of the chemistry prior to its introduction within proteins, we discovered enzymes capable of efficiently redirecting bacterial metabolism to the target chemistry for the first time. Thanks to the action of newly discovered N-monooxygenase enzymes, the engineered bacteria could produce nearly millimolar titers of the target chemistry at relatively low cell densities. We then found genetically encoded systems that allowed this chemistry to be placed within desired proteins. We were able to combine these strategies to create a single bacterium that could autonomously produce the para-nitro-phenylalanine building block and place it within desired proteins. Along the way, we gained considerable knowledge about the strategy of coupling metabolic engineering to genetic code expansion, including the importance of selectivity in the biosynthesis and incorporation steps, as well as the importance of biosynthesis rate and the affinity of the systems used for incorporation. Finally, we trained several undergraduate researchers as part of this project, including multiple who earned the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship, and we posted many educational videos about metabolic engineering and synthetic biology to YouTube under our Kunjapur Lab Academy channel.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2024
Modified by: Aditya M Kunjapur
